column2: COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. All travellers from 12 years and upwards arriving in Jamaica must present a certificate issued by a UKAS accredited laboratory showing a negative COVID-19 molecular (PCR, NAA, RNA) or Antigen test result, with the test taken within the 72 hours prior to the date of travel.
column3: Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to category. Since 1 March 2022, travellers are no longer required to quarantine on arrival, as long as they provide a negative test taken up to three days before arrival in Jamaica.
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Jamaica: All travellers from 12 years and upwards arriving in Jamaica must present a certificate issued by a UKAS accredited laboratory showing a negative COVID-19 molecular (PCR, NAA, RNA) or Antigen test result, with the test taken within the 72 hours prior to the date of travel.
Testing and screening on arrival: All travellers arriving in Jamaica may be tested for COVID-19 if assessed as high-risk as a result of exhibiting symptoms, exposure to persons who have tested positive, belonging to a high-risk group or other risk factors. Travellers may be screened for symptoms at the airport.


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Jamaica: Anyone with colds, coughs and flu symptoms is required to stay at home. Anyone who has tested positive for COVID must self-isolate until fully recovered.
*Public places and services: Some restrictions continue: • events must limit the number of persons in attendance to below 70% of the normal capacity of the venue; • mask-wearing in enclosed spaces to which the public has access, for example, supermarkets, banks, and tax collectorates, is mandatory. Mask-wearing in establishments that serve food, liquor or other drink for consumption within the premises is highly recommended; and
• certain restrictions may apply to hospitals, nursing homes, infirmaries and correctional facilities
Accommodation: Hotels and private rentals are open in Jamaica. Travellers are advised to confirm arrangements before travelling.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you will need to self-isolate until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment in Jamaica.
